questions.text: 34-year-old female presented with progressive pallor and organomegaly. Work up shows low Hb, platelet count of 25000/mm3. raised PT and aPTT. Peripheral smear is given. Which of the following fusion gene is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: PML RARA

  • Patient with features of blood caner is having low platelet count with elevated PT and aPTT. This implies DIC which is seen in M3 AML. Acute promyelocytic leukemia has PML-RARA rearrangement.

Incorrect options

RUNX1–RUNX1T1 is associated with AML with t(8;21) (M2).

IGH–NSD2 is associated with Lymphoid malignancies (rare).

BCR–ABL is associated with CML or Ph+ ALL.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of bleeding from nose and progressive pallor. Peripheral smear shows the presence of cells shown below. Which of the following is the most common chromosomal abnormality seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: t (15:17) 

  • Image shows myeloid cells with Auer rods in the cytoplasm. This coupled with bleeding manifestation implies association with acute promyelocytic leukaemia (M3 AML). It occurs due to t (15:17) translocation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, progressive pallor and recurrent nasal bleeds. Bone marrow aspiration shows 10% myeloblasts with abnormal eosinophils. Cytogenetic analysis reveals inv(16) (p13;q22). Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Acute myeloid leukemia

  • Marrow blast count of ≥20% is required, except for AML with the recurrent genetic abnormalities
    • t (15;17)
    • t (8;21)
    • inv (16)
    • t (16;16)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with early satiety and abdominal pain. On examination grossly enlarged spleen and liver is palpable Work up shows low Hb with WBC-50000/mm3 and platelet count of 6 lac/cu.mm. Which of the following will cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: t (9:22)

  • Enlarged spleen with high TLC is feature of CML. The cause is Philadelphia chromosome where a balanced translocation between chromosome 9 and 22 creates a bcr- abl1 fusion gene causing activation of tyrosine kinase and uncontrolled mitosis. CML in chronic phase has leucocytosis with thrombocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following chromosomal aberrations occur in topoisomerase II inhibitor–associated acute myeloid leukemia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: 11q23

  • Topoisomerase II inhibitor–associated leukaemia occurs 1–3 years after exposure, and affected individuals often have AML with monocytic features and aberrations involving chromosome11q23.
  • Alkylating agent associated leukaemia occurs 4–6 years after exposure and have monosomy/aberrations in chromosomes 5 and 7.

questions.text: Which type of AML shows extensive infiltration of skin, soft tissues, gingiva and meninges?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: Acute monocytic leukemia

  • Infiltration of skin and soft tissues called chloroma, gingival hyperplasia and CNS leukaemia due to meningeal infiltration is commonly seen with acute monocytic leukaemia with 11q23 abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is not responsible for AML
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: NOTCH1

  • NPM1, FLT3-ITD, and CEBPA mutations are commonly seen in AML and influence prognosis and treatment.
  • NOTCH1 mutations are primarily associated with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) and are not involved in AML pathogenesis.

questions.text: Arsenic trioxide is used for treatment of which of the following malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Acute promyelocytic leukemia

  • All trans retinoic acid and arsenic trioxide are used for management of APL

Mechanism of action of Arsenic trioxide

  1. Degradation of PML-RARA oncoprotein: It promotes ubiquitin-mediated proteasomal degradation of the abnormal PML-RARA fusion protein that blocks differentiation.
  2. Induction of apoptosis: ATO generates reactive oxygen species and mitochondrial damage, triggering programmed cell death of leukemic cells.
  3. Promotion of differentiation: Similar to ATRA, ATO helps leukemic promyelocytes mature into normal granulocytes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with acute promyelocytic leukemia is started on ATRA therapy. After 10 days, she develops fever, dyspnea, weight gain, and pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this complication?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Initiate high-dose corticosteroids

  • The patient has developed Differentiation Syndrome, a potentially life-threatening complication caused by rapid differentiation and cytokine release by malignant cells.
  • The syndrome is related to adhesion of differentiated neoplastic cells to the pulmonary vasculature endothelium.
  • Symptoms include fever, respiratory distress, weight gain, pleural/pericardial effusions, and pulmonary infiltrates. Early corticosteroid therapy with dexamethasone is the cornerstone of treatment and can be continued along with ATRA.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features is/are seen in patient with AML


	Gum hypertrophy
	Skin infiltration
	Lower extremity weakness
	Papilledema
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: 1,2,3,4

  • GUM hypertrophy (leukemic infiltration, most common in monocytic leukemia)
  • Skin infiltration or nodules ( leukemia infiltration, most common in monocytic leukemia)
  • Back pain, lower extremity weakness (spinal granulocytic sarcoma, most likely in t(8:21) patients)
  • Papilledema is explained by CNS leukemia
